what: Location Tests for High-Dimensional Problems Including Normal-Reference Approach
title: Location Tests for High-Dimensional Problems Including Normal-Reference Approach
text: R package NRAHDLTP includes latest methods based normal-reference approach test equality mean vectors high-dimensional samples possibly different covariance matrices. NRAHDLTP also used demonstrate implementation tests, catering two-sample problem, also general linear hypothesis testing (GLHT) problem. package provides easy user-friendly access tests. coded C++ allow reasonable execution time using Rcpp. except Rcpp, package strict dependencies order provide stable self-contained toolbox invites re-use. two real data sets NRAHDLTP: COVID19 corneal. Seven normal-refernece Approach Based Tests Two-sample Problem: ts_zgzc2020(), ts_zz2022(), ts_zzz2020(), tsbf_zwz2023(), tsbf_zz2022(), tsbf_zzgz2021(), tsbf_zzz2023(). Five normal-refernece Approach Based Tests GLHT Problem NRAHDLTP: glht_zgz2017(), glht_zz2022(), glht_zzz2022(), glhtbf_zz2022(), glhtbf_zzg2022(). Four others’ Tests Two-sample Problem NRAHDLTP: ts_bs1996(), ts_sd2008(), tsbf_cq2010(), tsbf_skk2013(). Five others’ test GLHT problem NRAHDLTP: glht_fhw2004(), glht_sf2006(), glht_ys2012(), glhtbf_zgz2017(), ks_s2007().

title: Location Tests for High-Dimensional Problems Including Normal-Reference Approach
text: can install load recent approved version CRAN : can install load recent development version NRAHDLTP GitHub :
code: # install the most recent approved version from CRAN install.packages("NRAHDLTP") # load the most recent approved version from CRAN library(NRAHDLTP) # Installing from GitHub requires you first install the devtools or remotes package install.packages("devtools") # Or install.packages("remotes")  # install the most recent development version from GitHub devtools::install_github("nie23wp8738/NRAHDLTP") # Or remotes::install_github("nie23wp8738/NRAHDLTP") # load the most recent development version from GitHub library(NRAHDLTP)

title: Location Tests for High-Dimensional Problems Including Normal-Reference Approach
code: library(NRAHDLTP)

title: Location Tests for High-Dimensional Problems Including Normal-Reference Approach
text: Package NRAHDLTP comes two real data sets:
code: # A COVID19 data set from NCBI with ID GSE152641. ?COVID19  # A corneal data set acquired during a keratoconus study. ?corneal

title: Location Tests for High-Dimensional Problems Including Normal-Reference Approach
text: simple example run one normal-reference approach based test tsbf_zwz2023 using data set COVID19:
code: data("COVID19") group1 <- as.matrix(COVID19[c(2:19, 82:87), ]) #healthy group1 group2 <- as.matrix(COVID19[-c(1:19, 82:87), ]) #patients group2 # The data matrix for tsbf_zwz2023 should be p by n, sometimes we should transpose the data matrix tsbf_zwz2023(t(group1),t(group2)) #>  #>  #>  #> data:   #> statistic = 4.1877, df1 = 2.7324, df2 = 171.7596, p-value = 0.008673

title: Location Tests for High-Dimensional Problems Including Normal-Reference Approach
text: simple example run one normal-reference approach based test glhtbf_zzg2022 using data set corneal:
code: data("corneal") p <- dim(corneal)[2] k <- 4 Y <- list() group1 <- as.matrix(corneal[1:43, ]) #normal group2 <- as.matrix(corneal[44:57, ]) #unilateral suspect group3 <- as.matrix(corneal[58:78, ]) #suspect group4 <- as.matrix(corneal[79:150, ]) #clinical leratoconus Y[[1]] <- t(group1) Y[[2]] <- t(group2) Y[[3]] <- t(group3) Y[[4]] <- t(group4) dim(Y[[1]]) #> [1] 2000   43 dim(Y[[2]]) #> [1] 2000   14 dim(Y[[3]]) #> [1] 2000   21 dim(Y[[4]]) #> [1] 2000   72 n <- c(43,14,21,72) G <- cbind(diag(k-1),rep(-1,k-1)) glhtbf_zzg2022(Y,G,n,p) #>  #>  #>  #> data:   #> statistic = 159.73, df = 6.1652, beta = 6.1464, p-value = 0.0002577

what: NRAHDLTP: Location Tests for High-Dimensional Problems Including Normal-Reference Approach — NRAHDLTP-package
title: NRAHDLTP: Location Tests for High-Dimensional Problems Including Normal-Reference Approach — NRAHDLTP-package
text: provide collection various classical tests latest normal-reference approach tests comparing high-dimensional mean vectors including two-sample general linear hypothesis testing (GLHT) problem. others’ tests two-sample problem [see Bai, Zhidong, Hewa Saranadasa.(1996) https://www.jstor.org/stable/24306018; Chen, Song Xi, Ying-Li Qin.(2010) doi:10.1214/09-aos716 ; Srivastava, Muni S., Meng Du.(2008) doi:10.1016/j.jmva.2006.11.002 ; Srivastava, Muni S., Shota Katayama, Yutaka Kano.(2013)doi:10.1016/j.jmva.2012.08.014 ]. Normal-reference approach based tests two-sample problem [see Zhang, Jin-Ting, Jia Guo, Bu Zhou, Ming-Yen Cheng.(2020) doi:10.1080/01621459.2019.1604366 ; Zhang, Jin-Ting, Bu Zhou, Jia Guo, Tianming Zhu.(2021) doi:10.1016/j.jspi.2020.11.008 ; Zhang, Liang, Tianming Zhu, Jin-Ting Zhang.(2020) doi:10.1016/j.ecosta.2019.12.002 ; Zhang, Liang, Tianming Zhu, Jin-Ting Zhang.(2023) doi:10.1080/02664763.2020.1834516 ; Zhang, Jin-Ting, Tianming Zhu.(2022) doi:10.1080/10485252.2021.2015768 ; Zhang, Jin-Ting, Tianming Zhu.(2022) doi:10.1007/s42519-021-00232-w ; Zhu, Tianming, Pengfei Wang, Jin-Ting Zhang.(2023) doi:10.1007/s00180-023-01433-6 ]. others’ tests GLHT problem [see Fujikoshi, Yasunori, Tetsuto Himeno, Hirofumi Wakaki.(2004) doi:10.14490/jjss.34.19 ; Srivastava, Muni S., Yasunori Fujikoshi.(2006) doi:10.1016/j.jmva.2005.08.010 ; Yamada, Takayuki, Muni S. Srivastava.(2012) doi:10.1080/03610926.2011.581786 ; Schott, James R.(2007) doi:10.1016/j.jmva.2006.11.007 ; Zhou, Bu, Jia Guo, Jin-Ting Zhang.(2017) doi:10.1016/j.jspi.2017.03.005 ]. Normal-reference approach based tests GLHT problem [see Zhang, Jin-Ting, Jia Guo, Bu Zhou.(2017) doi:10.1016/j.jmva.2017.01.002 ; Zhang, Jin-Ting, Bu Zhou, Jia Guo.(2022) doi:10.1016/j.jmva.2021.104816 ; Zhu, Tianming, Liang Zhang, Jin-Ting Zhang.(2022) doi:10.5705/ss.202020.0362 ; Zhu, Tianming, Jin-Ting Zhang.(2022) doi:10.1007/s00180-021-01110-6 ; Zhang, Jin-Ting, Tianming Zhu.(2022) doi:10.1016/j.csda.2021.107385 ].

title: Test for proposed by Fujikoshi et al. (2004) — glht_fhw2004
text: high-dimensional linear regression model can expressed $$\boldsymbol{Y}=\boldsymbol{X\Theta}+\boldsymbol{\epsilon},$$ \(\Theta\) \(k\times p\) unknown parameter matrix \(\boldsymbol{\epsilon}\) \(n\times p\) error matrix. interest test following GLHT problem $$H_0: \boldsymbol{C\Theta}=\boldsymbol{0}, \quad \text { vs. } \quad H_1: \boldsymbol{C\Theta} \neq \boldsymbol{0}.$$ Fujikoshi et al. (2004) proposed following test statistic: $$T_{FHW}=\sqrt{p}\left[(n-k)\frac{\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{S}_h)}{\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{S}_e)}-q\right],$$ \(\boldsymbol{S}_h\) \(\boldsymbol{S}_e\) matrices sums squares products due hypothesis error, respecitively. showed null hypothesis, \(T_{FHW}\) asymptotically normally distributed.

title: Test for proposed by Fujikoshi et al. (2004) — glht_fhw2004
text: Fujikoshi Y, Himeno T, Wakaki H (2004). “Asymptotic results high dimensional MANOVA test power comparison dimension large compared sample size.” Journal Japan Statistical Society, 34(1), 19--26. doi:10.14490/jjss.34.19 .

title: Test for proposed by Fujikoshi et al. (2004) — glht_fhw2004
code: set.seed(1234) k <- 3 q <- k-1 p <- 50 n <- c(25,30,40) rho <- 0.01 Theta <- matrix(rep(0,k*p),nrow=k) X <- matrix(c(rep(1,n[1]),rep(0,sum(n)),rep(1,n[2]),rep(0,sum(n)),rep(1,n[3])),ncol=k,nrow=sum(n)) y <- (-2*sqrt(1-rho)+sqrt(4*(1-rho)+4*p*rho))/(2*p) x <- y+sqrt((1-rho)) Gamma <- matrix(rep(y,p*p),nrow=p) diag(Gamma) <- rep(x,p) U <- matrix(ncol = sum(n),nrow=p) for(i in 1:sum(n)){ U[,i] <- rnorm(p,0,1) } Y <- X%*%Theta+t(U)%*%Gamma C <- cbind(diag(q),-rep(1,q)) glht_fhw2004(Y,X,C) #>  #>  #>  #> data:   #> statistic = 0.56536, p-value = 0.2859 #>

title: Test proposed by Srivastava and Fujikoshi (2006) — glht_sf2006
text: high-dimensional linear regression model can expressed $$\boldsymbol{Y}=\boldsymbol{X\Theta}+\boldsymbol{\epsilon},$$ \(\Theta\) \(k\times p\) unknown parameter matrix \(\boldsymbol{\epsilon}\) \(n\times p\) error matrix. interest test following GLHT problem $$H_0: \boldsymbol{C\Theta}=\boldsymbol{0}, \quad \text { vs. } \quad H_1: \boldsymbol{C\Theta} \neq \boldsymbol{0}.$$ Srivastava Fujikoshi (2006) proposed following test statistic: $$T_{SF}=\left[2q\hat{}_2(1+n^{-1}q)\right]^{-1/2}\left[\frac{\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{B})}{\sqrt{p}}-\frac{q}{\sqrt{n}}\frac{\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{W})}{\sqrt{np}}\right].$$ \(\boldsymbol{W}\) \(\boldsymbol{B}\) matrix sum squares products due error error, respectively, \(\hat{}_2=[\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{W}^2)-\operatorname{tr}^2(\boldsymbol{W})/n]/[(n-1)(n+2)p]\). showed null hypothesis, \(T_{SF}\) asymptotically normally distributed.

title: Test proposed by Srivastava and Fujikoshi (2006) — glht_sf2006
text: Srivastava MS, Fujikoshi Y (2006). “Multivariate analysis variance fewer observations dimension.” Journal Multivariate Analysis, 97(9), 1927--1940. doi:10.1016/j.jmva.2005.08.010 .

title: Test proposed by Srivastava and Fujikoshi (2006) — glht_sf2006
code: set.seed(1234) k <- 3 q <- k-1 p <- 50 n <- c(25,30,40) rho <- 0.01 Theta <- matrix(rep(0,k*p),nrow=k) X <- matrix(c(rep(1,n[1]),rep(0,sum(n)),rep(1,n[2]),rep(0,sum(n)),rep(1,n[3])),ncol=k,nrow=sum(n)) y <- (-2*sqrt(1-rho)+sqrt(4*(1-rho)+4*p*rho))/(2*p) x <- y+sqrt((1-rho)) Gamma <- matrix(rep(y,p*p),nrow=p) diag(Gamma) <- rep(x,p) U <- matrix(ncol = sum(n),nrow=p) for(i in 1:sum(n)){ U[,i] <- rnorm(p,0,1) } Y <- X%*%Theta+t(U)%*%Gamma C <- cbind(diag(q),-rep(1,q)) glht_sf2006(Y,X,C) #>  #>  #>  #> data:   #> statistic = 0.56836, p-value = 0.2849 #>

title: Test proposed by Yamada and Srivastava (2012) — glht_ys2012
text: high-dimensional linear regression model can expressed $$\boldsymbol{Y}=\boldsymbol{X\Theta}+\boldsymbol{\epsilon},$$ \(\Theta\) \(k\times p\) unknown parameter matrix \(\boldsymbol{\epsilon}\) \(n\times p\) error matrix. interest test following GLHT problem $$H_0: \boldsymbol{C\Theta}=\boldsymbol{0}, \quad \text { vs. } H_1: \boldsymbol{C\Theta} \neq \boldsymbol{0}.$$ Yamada Srivastava (2012) proposed following test statistic: $$T_{YS}=\frac{(n-k)\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{S}_h\boldsymbol{D}_{\boldsymbol{S}_e}^{-1})-(n-k)pq/(n-k-2)}{\sqrt{2q[\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{R}^2)-p^2/(n-k)]c_{p,n}}},$$ \(\boldsymbol{S}_h\) \(\boldsymbol{S}_e\) variation matrices due hypothesis error, respectively, \(\boldsymbol{D}_{\boldsymbol{S}_e}\) \(\boldsymbol{R}\) diagonal matrix diagonal elements \(\boldsymbol{S}_e\) sample correlation matrix, respectively. \(c_{p, n}\) adjustment coefficient proposed Yamada Srivastava (2012). showed null hypothesis, \(T_{YS}\) asymptotically normally distributed.

title: Test proposed by Yamada and Srivastava (2012) — glht_ys2012

code: set.seed(1234) k <- 3 q <- k-1 p <- 50 n <- c(25,30,40) rho <- 0.01 Theta <- matrix(rep(0,k*p),nrow=k) X <- matrix(c(rep(1,n[1]),rep(0,sum(n)),rep(1,n[2]),rep(0,sum(n)),rep(1,n[3])),ncol=k,nrow=sum(n)) y <- (-2*sqrt(1-rho)+sqrt(4*(1-rho)+4*p*rho))/(2*p) x <- y+sqrt((1-rho)) Gamma <- matrix(rep(y,p*p),nrow=p) diag(Gamma) <- rep(x,p) U <- matrix(ncol = sum(n),nrow=p) for(i in 1:sum(n)){ U[,i] <- rnorm(p,0,1) } Y <- X%*%Theta+t(U)%*%Gamma C <- cbind(diag(q),-rep(1,q)) glht_ys2012(Y,X,C) #>  #>  #>  #> data:   #> statistic = 0.33789, cpn = 1.2185, p-value = 0.3677 #>

title: Test proposed by Zhang et al. (2017) — glht_zgz2017
text: Suppose following \(k\) independent high-dimensional samples: $$ \boldsymbol{y}_{i1},\ldots,\boldsymbol{y}_{in_i}, \;\operatorname{\; ..d. \; }\; \operatorname{E}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\mu}_i,\; \operatorname{Cov}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\Sigma},\;=1,\ldots,k. $$ interest test following GLHT problem: $$H_0: \boldsymbol{G M}=\boldsymbol{0}, \quad \text { vs. } \quad H_1: \boldsymbol{G M} \neq \boldsymbol{0},$$ \(\boldsymbol{M}=(\boldsymbol{\mu}_1,\ldots,\boldsymbol{\mu}_k)^\top\) \(k\times p\) matrix collecting \(k\) mean vectors \(\boldsymbol{G}:q\times k\) known full-rank coefficient matrix \(\operatorname{rank}(\boldsymbol{G})<k\). Zhang et al. (2017) proposed following test statistic: $$ T_{ZGZ}=\|\boldsymbol{C \hat{\mu}}\|^2, $$ \(\boldsymbol{C}=[(\boldsymbol{G D G}^\top)^{-1/2}\boldsymbol{G}]\otimes\boldsymbol{}_p\), \(\hat{\boldsymbol{\mu}}=(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_1^\top,\ldots,\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_k^\top)^\top\), \(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_{},=1,\ldots,k\) sample mean vectors \(\boldsymbol{D}=\operatorname{diag}(1/n_1,\ldots,1/n_k)\). showed null hypothesis, \(T_{ZGZ}\) chi-squared-type mixture normal non-normal limiting distribution.

title: Test proposed by Zhang et al. (2017) — glht_zgz2017
text: Zhang J, Guo J, Zhou B (2017). “Linear hypothesis testing high-dimensional one-way MANOVA.” Journal Multivariate Analysis, 155, 200--216. doi:10.1016/j.jmva.2017.01.002 .

title: Test proposed by Zhang et al. (2017) — glht_zgz2017
code: set.seed(1234) k <- 3 p <- 50 n <- c(25, 30, 40) rho <- 0.1 M <- matrix(rep(0, k * p), nrow = k, ncol = p) y <- (-2 * sqrt(1 - rho) + sqrt(4 * (1 - rho) + 4 * p * rho)) / (2 * p) x <- y + sqrt((1 - rho)) Gamma <- matrix(rep(y, p * p), nrow = p) diag(Gamma) <- rep(x, p) Y <- list() for (g in 1:k) {   Z <- matrix(rnorm(n[g] * p, mean = 0, sd = 1), p, n[g])   Y[[g]] <- Gamma %*% Z + t(t(M[g, ])) %*% (rep(1, n[g])) } G <- cbind(diag(k - 1), rep(-1, k - 1)) glht_zgz2017(Y, G, n, p) #>  #>  #>  #> data:   #> statistic = 103.56, df = 70.544, p-value = 0.353 #>

title: Test proposed by Zhu and Zhang (2022) — glht_zz2022
text: Suppose following \(k\) independent high-dimensional samples: $$ \boldsymbol{y}_{i1},\ldots,\boldsymbol{y}_{in_i}, \;\operatorname{\; ..d. \; }\; \operatorname{E}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\mu}_i,\; \operatorname{Cov}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\Sigma},\; =1,\ldots,k. $$ interest test following GLHT problem: $$H_0: \boldsymbol{G M}=\boldsymbol{0}, \quad \text { vs. } \quad H_1: \boldsymbol{G M} \neq \boldsymbol{0},$$ \(\boldsymbol{M}=(\boldsymbol{\mu}_1,\ldots,\boldsymbol{\mu}_k)^\top\) \(k\times p\) matrix collecting \(k\) mean vectors \(\boldsymbol{G}:q\times k\) known full-rank coefficient matrix \(\operatorname{rank}(\boldsymbol{G})<k\). Zhu Zhang (2022) proposed following test statistic: $$ T_{ZZ}=\|\boldsymbol{C} \hat{\boldsymbol{\mu}}\|^2-q \operatorname{tr}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}), $$ \(\boldsymbol{C}=[(\boldsymbol{G D G}^\top)^{-1/2}\boldsymbol{G}]\otimes\boldsymbol{}_p\), \(\hat{\boldsymbol{\mu}}=(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_1^\top,\ldots,\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_k^\top)^\top\), \(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_{},=1,\ldots,k\) sample mean vectors \(\hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}\) usual pooled sample covariance matrix \(k\) samples. showed null hypothesis, \(T_{ZZ}\) chi-squared-type mixture normal non-normal limiting distribution.

title: Test proposed by Zhu and Zhang (2022) — glht_zz2022
text: Zhu T, Zhang J (2022). “Linear hypothesis testing high-dimensional one-way MANOVA: new normal reference approach.” Computational Statistics, 37(1), 1--27. doi:10.1007/s00180-021-01110-6 .

title: Test proposed by Zhu and Zhang (2022) — glht_zz2022
code: set.seed(1234) k <- 3 p <- 50 n <- c(25, 30, 40) rho <- 0.1 M <- matrix(rep(0, k * p), nrow = k, ncol = p) y <- (-2 * sqrt(1 - rho) + sqrt(4 * (1 - rho) + 4 * p * rho)) / (2 * p) x <- y + sqrt((1 - rho)) Gamma <- matrix(rep(y, p * p), nrow = p) diag(Gamma) <- rep(x, p) Y <- list() for (g in 1:k) {   Z <- matrix(rnorm(n[g] * p, mean = 0, sd = 1), p, n[g])   Y[[g]] <- Gamma %*% Z + t(t(M[g, ])) %*% (rep(1, n[g])) } G <- cbind(diag(k - 1), rep(-1, k - 1)) glht_zz2022(Y, G, n, p) #>  #>  #>  #> data:   #> statistic = 5.345, df = 18.8571, beta1 = 2.7212, beta0 = -51.3143, #> p-value = 0.3382 #>

code: set.seed(1234) k <- 3 q <- k - 1 p <- 50 n <- c(25, 30, 40) rho <- 0.01 Theta <- matrix(rep(0, k * p), nrow = k) X <- matrix(c(rep(1, n[1]), rep(0, sum(n)), rep(1, n[2]), rep(0, sum(n)), rep(1, n[3])),   ncol = k, nrow = sum(n) ) y <- (-2 * sqrt(1 - rho) + sqrt(4 * (1 - rho) + 4 * p * rho)) / (2 * p) x <- y + sqrt((1 - rho)) Gamma <- matrix(rep(y, p * p), nrow = p) diag(Gamma) <- rep(x, p) U <- matrix(ncol = sum(n), nrow = p) for (i in 1:sum(n)) {   U[, i] <- rnorm(p, 0, 1) } Y <- X %*% Theta + t(U) %*% Gamma C <- cbind(diag(q), -rep(1, q)) glht_zzz2022(Y, X, C) #>  #>  #>  #> data:   #> statistic = 1.0496, df = 105.45, p-value = 0.3447 #>

title: Test proposed by Zhou et al. (2017) — glhtbf_zgz2017
text: Suppose following \(k\) independent high-dimensional samples: $$ \boldsymbol{y}_{i1},\ldots,\boldsymbol{y}_{in_i}, \;\operatorname{\; ..d. \; }\; \operatorname{E}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\mu}_i,\; \operatorname{Cov}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_i,=1,\ldots,k. $$ interest test following GLHT problem: $$H_0: \boldsymbol{G M}=\boldsymbol{0}, \quad \text { vs. } H_1: \boldsymbol{G M} \neq \boldsymbol{0},$$ \(\boldsymbol{M}=(\boldsymbol{\mu}_1,\ldots,\boldsymbol{\mu}_k)^\top\) \(k\times p\) matrix collecting \(k\) mean vectors \(\boldsymbol{G}:q\times k\) known full-rank coefficient matrix \(\operatorname{rank}(\boldsymbol{G})<k\). Let  \(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_{},=1,\ldots,k\) sample mean vectors \(\hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_i,=1,\ldots,k\) sample covariance matrices. Zhou et al. (2017) proposed following U-statistic based test statistic: $$ T_{ZGZ}=\|\boldsymbol{C \hat{\mu}}\|^2-\sum_{=1}^kh_{ii}\operatorname{tr}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_i)/n_i, $$ \(\boldsymbol{C}=[(\boldsymbol{G D G}^\top)^{-1/2}\boldsymbol{G}]\otimes\boldsymbol{}_p\), \(\boldsymbol{D}=\operatorname{diag}(1/n_1,\ldots,1/n_k)\), \(h_{ij}\) \((,j)\)th entry \(k\times k\) matrix \(\boldsymbol{H}=\boldsymbol{G}^\top\boldsymbol{G}\). showed null hypothesis, \(T_{ZGZ}\) asymptotically normally distributed.

title: Test proposed by Zhou et al. (2017) — glhtbf_zgz2017
code: set.seed(1234) k <- 3 p <- 50 n <- c(25, 30, 40) rho <- 0.1 M <- matrix(rep(0, k * p), nrow = k, ncol = p) avec <- seq(1, k) Y <- list() for (g in 1:k) {   a <- avec[g]   y <- (-2 * sqrt(a * (1 - rho)) + sqrt(4 * a * (1 - rho) + 4 * p * a * rho)) / (2 * p)   x <- y + sqrt(a * (1 - rho))   Gamma <- matrix(rep(y, p * p), nrow = p)   diag(Gamma) <- rep(x, p)   Z <- matrix(rnorm(n[g] * p, mean = 0, sd = 1), p, n[g])   Y[[g]] <- Gamma %*% Z + t(t(M[g, ])) %*% (rep(1, n[g])) } G <- cbind(diag(k - 1), rep(-1, k - 1)) glhtbf_zgz2017(Y, G, n, p) #>  #>  #>  #> data:   #> statistic = 3.3665, p-value = 0.4587 #>

text: Suppose following \(k\) independent high-dimensional samples: $$ \boldsymbol{y}_{i1},\ldots,\boldsymbol{y}_{in_i}, \;\operatorname{\; ..d. \; }\; \operatorname{E}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\mu}_i,\; \operatorname{Cov}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_i,=1,\ldots,k. $$ interest test following GLHT problem: $$H_0: \boldsymbol{G M}=\boldsymbol{0}, \quad \text { vs. } H_1: \boldsymbol{G M} \neq \boldsymbol{0},$$ \(\boldsymbol{M}=(\boldsymbol{\mu}_1,\ldots,\boldsymbol{\mu}_k)^\top\) \(k\times p\) matrix collecting \(k\) mean vectors \(\boldsymbol{G}:q\times k\) known full-rank coefficient matrix \(\operatorname{rank}(\boldsymbol{G})<k\). Let  \(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_{},=1,\ldots,k\) sample mean vectors \(\hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_i,=1,\ldots,k\) sample covariance matrices. Zhang Zhu (2022) proposed following U-statistic based test statistic: $$ T_{ZZ}=\|\boldsymbol{C \hat{\mu}}\|^2-\sum_{=1}^kh_{ii}\operatorname{tr}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_i)/n_i, $$ \(\boldsymbol{C}=[(\boldsymbol{G D G}^\top)^{-1/2}\boldsymbol{G}]\otimes\boldsymbol{}_p\), \(\boldsymbol{D}=\operatorname{diag}(1/n_1,\ldots,1/n_k)\), \(h_{ij}\) \((,j)\)th entry \(k\times k\) matrix \(\boldsymbol{H}=\boldsymbol{G}^\top\boldsymbol{G}\).

title: Test proposed by Zhang and Zhu (2022) — glhtbf_zz2022
text: Zhang J, Zhu T (2022). “new normal reference test linear hypothesis testing high-dimensional heteroscedastic one-way MANOVA.” Computational Statistics & Data Analysis, 168, 107385. doi:10.1016/j.csda.2021.107385 .

title: Test proposed by Zhang and Zhu (2022) — glhtbf_zz2022
code: set.seed(1234) k <- 3 p <- 50 n <- c(25, 30, 40) rho <- 0.1 M <- matrix(rep(0, k * p), nrow = k, ncol = p) avec <- seq(1, k) Y <- list() for (g in 1:k) {   a <- avec[g]   y <- (-2 * sqrt(a * (1 - rho)) + sqrt(4 * a * (1 - rho) + 4 * p * a * rho)) / (2 * p)   x <- y + sqrt(a * (1 - rho))   Gamma <- matrix(rep(y, p * p), nrow = p)   diag(Gamma) <- rep(x, p)   Z <- matrix(rnorm(n[g] * p, mean = 0, sd = 1), p, n[g])   Y[[g]] <- Gamma %*% Z + t(t(M[g, ])) %*% (rep(1, n[g])) } G <- cbind(diag(k - 1), rep(-1, k - 1)) glhtbf_zz2022(Y, G, n, p) #>  #>  #>  #> data:   #> statistic = 3.3665, df = 19.8766, beta1 = 5.1553, beta0 = -102.4706, #> p-value = 0.4176 #>

(2022) proposed following test statistic: $$ T_{ZZG}=\|\boldsymbol{C} \hat{\boldsymbol{\mu}}\|^2, $$ \(\boldsymbol{C}=[(\boldsymbol{G D G}^\top)^{-1/2}\boldsymbol{G}]\otimes\boldsymbol{}_p\) \(\boldsymbol{D}=\operatorname{diag}(1/n_1,\ldots,1/n_k)\), \(\hat{\boldsymbol{\mu}}=(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_1^\top,\ldots,\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_k^\top)^\top\) \(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_{},=1,\ldots,k\) sample mean vectors. showed null hypothesis, \(T_{ZZG}\) chi-squared-type mixture normal non-normal limiting distribution.

title: Test proposed by Schott (2007) — ks_s2007
text: Suppose following \(k\) independent high-dimensional samples: $$ \boldsymbol{y}_{i1},\ldots,\boldsymbol{y}_{in_i}, \;\operatorname{\; ..d. \; }\; \operatorname{E}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\mu}_i,\; \operatorname{Cov}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\Sigma},=1,\ldots,k. $$ interest test following one-way MANOVA problem: $$H_0: \boldsymbol{\mu}_1=\cdots=\boldsymbol{\mu}_k, \quad \text { vs. }\; H_1: H_0 \;\operatorname{\; \; ture}.$$ Schott (2007) proposed following test statistic: $$  T_{S}=[\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{H})/h-\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{E})/e]/\sqrt{N-1},  $$ \(\boldsymbol{H}=\sum_{=1}^kn_i(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_i-\bar{\boldsymbol{y}})(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_i-\bar{\boldsymbol{y}})^\top\), \(\boldsymbol{E}=\sum_{=1}^k\sum_{j=1}^{n_i}(\boldsymbol{y}_{ij}-\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_{})(\boldsymbol{y}_{ij}-\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_{})^\top\), \(h=k-1\), \(e=N-k\), \(N=n_1+\cdots+n_k\). showed null hypothesis, \(T_{S}\) asymptotically normally distributed.

title: Test proposed by Schott (2007) — ks_s2007
text: Schott JR (2007). “high-dimensional tests one-way MANOVA.” Journal Multivariate Analysis, 98(9), 1825--1839. doi:10.1016/j.jmva.2006.11.007 .

title: Test proposed by Schott (2007) — ks_s2007
code: set.seed(1234) k <- 3 p <- 50 n <- c(25, 30, 40) rho <- 0.1 M <- matrix(rep(0, k * p), nrow = k, ncol = p) y <- (-2 * sqrt(1 - rho) + sqrt(4 * (1 - rho) + 4 * p * rho)) / (2 * p) x <- y + sqrt((1 - rho)) Gamma <- matrix(rep(y, p * p), nrow = p) diag(Gamma) <- rep(x, p) Y <- list() for (g in 1:k) {   Z <- matrix(rnorm(n[g] * p, mean = 0, sd = 1), p, n[g])   Y[[g]] <- Gamma %*% Z + t(t(M[g, ])) %*% (rep(1, n[g])) } ks_s2007(Y, n, p) #>  #>  #>  #> data:   #> statistic = 0.31984, p-value = 0.3745 #>

title: Test proposed by Bai and Saranadasa (1996) — ts_bs1996
text: Suppose two independent high-dimensional samples: $$ \boldsymbol{y}_{i1},\ldots,\boldsymbol{y}_{in_i}, \;\operatorname{\; ..d. \; }\; \operatorname{E}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\mu}_i,\; \operatorname{Cov}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\Sigma},=1,2. $$ primary object test $$H_{0}: \boldsymbol{\mu}_1 = \boldsymbol{\mu}_2\; \operatorname{versus}\; H_{1}: \boldsymbol{\mu}_1 \neq \boldsymbol{\mu}_2.$$ Bai Saranadasa (1996) proposed following centralised \(L^2\)-norm-based test statistic: $$T_{BS} = \frac{n_1n_2}{n} \|\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_1 - \bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_2\|^2-\operatorname{tr}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}),$$  \(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_{},=1,2\) sample mean vectors \(\hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}\) pooled sample covariance matrix. showed null hypothesis, \(T_{BS}\) asymptotically normally distributed.

text: Suppose two independent high-dimensional samples: $$ \boldsymbol{y}_{i1},\ldots,\boldsymbol{y}_{in_i}, \;\operatorname{\; ..d. \; }\; \operatorname{E}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\mu}_i,\; \operatorname{Cov}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\Sigma},=1,2. $$ primary object test $$H_{0}: \boldsymbol{\mu}_1 = \boldsymbol{\mu}_2\; \operatorname{versus}\; H_{1}: \boldsymbol{\mu}_1 \neq \boldsymbol{\mu}_2.$$ Srivastava Du (2008) proposed following test statistic: $$T_{SD} = \frac{\frac{n_1n_2}{n_1+n_2}(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_1 - \bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_2)^\top \boldsymbol{D}_S^{-1}(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_1 - \bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_2) - \frac{(n_1+n_2-2)p}{n_1+n_2-4}}{\sqrt{2 \left[\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{R}^2) - \frac{p^2}{n-2}\right] c_{p, n}}},$$ \(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_{},=1,2\) sample mean vectors, \(\boldsymbol{D}_S\) diagonal matrix sample variance, \(\boldsymbol{R}\) sample correlation matrix \(c_{p, n}\) adjustment coefficient proposed Srivastava Du (2008). showed null hypothesis, \(T_{SD}\) asymptotically normally distributed.

code: set.seed(1234) n1 <- 20 n2 <- 30 p <- 50 mu1 <- t(t(rep(0, p))) mu2 <- mu1 rho1 <- 0.1 rho2 <- 0.2 a1 <- 1 a2 <- 2 w1 <- (-2 * sqrt(a1 * (1 - rho1)) + sqrt(4 * a1 * (1 - rho1) + 4 * p * a1 * rho1)) / (2 * p) x1 <- w1 + sqrt(a1 * (1 - rho1)) Gamma1 <- matrix(rep(w1, p * p), nrow = p) diag(Gamma1) <- rep(x1, p) w2 <- (-2 * sqrt(a2 * (1 - rho2)) + sqrt(4 * a2 * (1 - rho2) + 4 * p * a2 * rho2)) / (2 * p) x2 <- w2 + sqrt(a2 * (1 - rho2)) Gamma2 <- matrix(rep(w2, p * p), nrow = p) diag(Gamma2) <- rep(x2, p) Z1 <- matrix(rnorm(n1*p,mean = 0,sd = 1), p, n1) Z2 <- matrix(rnorm(n2*p,mean = 0,sd = 1), p, n2) y1 <- Gamma1 %*% Z1 + mu1%*%(rep(1,n1)) y2 <- Gamma2 %*% Z2 + mu2%*%(rep(1,n2)) tsbf_cq2010(y1, y2) #>  #>  #>  #> data:   #> statistic = 0.14165, p-value = 0.4437 #>

title: Test proposed by Srivastava et al. (2013) — tsbf_skk2013
text: Suppose two independent high-dimensional samples: $$ \boldsymbol{y}_{i1},\ldots,\boldsymbol{y}_{in_i}, \;\operatorname{\; ..d. \; }\; \operatorname{E}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\mu}_i,\; \operatorname{Cov}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_i,=1,2. $$ primary object test $$H_{0}: \boldsymbol{\mu}_1 = \boldsymbol{\mu}_2\; \operatorname{versus}\; H_{1}: \boldsymbol{\mu}_1 \neq \boldsymbol{\mu}_2.$$ Srivastava et al. (2013) proposed following test statistic: $$T_{SKK} = \frac{(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_1 - \bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_2)^\top \hat{\boldsymbol{D}}^{-1}(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_1 - \bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_2) - p}{\sqrt{2 \widehat{\operatorname{Var}}(\hat{q}_n) c_{p,n}}},$$ \(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_{},=1,2\) sample mean vectors, \(\hat{\boldsymbol{D}}=\hat{\boldsymbol{D}}_1/n_1+\hat{\boldsymbol{D}}_2/n_2\) \(\hat{\boldsymbol{D}}_i,=1,2\) diagonal matrices consisting diagonal elements sample covariance matrices. \(\widehat{\operatorname{Var}}(\hat{q}_n)\) given equation (1.18) Srivastava et al. (2013),  \(c_{p, n}\) adjustment coefficient proposed Srivastava et al. (2013). showed null hypothesis, \(T_{SKK}\) asymptotically normally distributed.

title: Test proposed by Srivastava et al. (2013) — tsbf_skk2013
text: Srivastava MS, Katayama S, Kano Y (2013). “two sample test high dimensional data.” Journal Multivariate Analysis, 114, 349--358. doi:10.1016/j.jmva.2012.08.014 .

title: Test proposed by Srivastava et al. (2013) — tsbf_skk2013
code: set.seed(1234) n1 <- 20 n2 <- 30 p <- 50 mu1 <- t(t(rep(0, p))) mu2 <- mu1 rho1 <- 0.1 rho2 <- 0.2 a1 <- 1 a2 <- 2 w1 <- (-2 * sqrt(a1 * (1 - rho1)) + sqrt(4 * a1 * (1 - rho1) + 4 * p * a1 * rho1)) / (2 * p) x1 <- w1 + sqrt(a1 * (1 - rho1)) Gamma1 <- matrix(rep(w1, p * p), nrow = p) diag(Gamma1) <- rep(x1, p) w2 <- (-2 * sqrt(a2 * (1 - rho2)) + sqrt(4 * a2 * (1 - rho2) + 4 * p * a2 * rho2)) / (2 * p) x2 <- w2 + sqrt(a2 * (1 - rho2)) Gamma2 <- matrix(rep(w2, p * p), nrow = p) diag(Gamma2) <- rep(x2, p) Z1 <- matrix(rnorm(n1*p,mean = 0,sd = 1), p, n1) Z2 <- matrix(rnorm(n2*p,mean = 0,sd = 1), p, n2) y1 <- Gamma1 %*% Z1 + mu1%*%(rep(1,n1)) y2 <- Gamma2 %*% Z2 + mu2%*%(rep(1,n2)) tsbf_skk2013(y1, y2) #>  #>  #>  #> data:   #> statistic = -0.10736, cpn = 1.4402, p-value = 0.5427 #>

title: Test proposed by Zhu et al. (2023) — tsbf_zwz2023
text: Suppose two independent high-dimensional samples: $$ \boldsymbol{y}_{i1},\ldots,\boldsymbol{y}_{in_i}, \;\operatorname{\; ..d. \; }\; \operatorname{E}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\mu}_i,\; \operatorname{Cov}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_i,\; =1,2. $$ primary object test $$H_{0}: \boldsymbol{\mu}_1 = \boldsymbol{\mu}_2\; \operatorname{versus}\; H_{1}: \boldsymbol{\mu}_1 \neq \boldsymbol{\mu}_2.$$ Zhu et al. (2023) proposed following test statistic: $$T_{ZWZ}=\frac{n_1n_2n^{-1}\|\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_1-\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_2\|^2}{\operatorname{tr}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}_n)},$$  \(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_{},=1,2\) sample mean vectors \(\hat{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}_n\) estimator \(\operatorname{Cov}[(n_1n_2/n)^{1/2}(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_1-\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_2)]\). showed null hypothesis, \(T_{ZWZ}\) F-type mixture normal non-normal limiting distribution.

title: Test proposed by Zhu et al. (2023) — tsbf_zwz2023
text: Zhu T, Wang P, Zhang J (2023). “Two-sample Behrens--Fisher problems high-dimensional data: normal reference F-type test.” Computational Statistics, 1--24. doi:10.1007/s00180-023-01433-6 .

title: Test proposed by Zhu et al. (2023) — tsbf_zwz2023
code: set.seed(1234) n1 <- 20 n2 <- 30 p <- 50 mu1 <- t(t(rep(0, p))) mu2 <- mu1 rho1 <- 0.1 rho2 <- 0.2 a1 <- 1 a2 <- 2 w1 <- (-2 * sqrt(a1 * (1 - rho1)) + sqrt(4 * a1 * (1 - rho1) + 4 * p * a1 * rho1)) / (2 * p) x1 <- w1 + sqrt(a1 * (1 - rho1)) Gamma1 <- matrix(rep(w1, p * p), nrow = p) diag(Gamma1) <- rep(x1, p) w2 <- (-2 * sqrt(a2 * (1 - rho2)) + sqrt(4 * a2 * (1 - rho2) + 4 * p * a2 * rho2)) / (2 * p) x2 <- w2 + sqrt(a2 * (1 - rho2)) Gamma2 <- matrix(rep(w2, p * p), nrow = p) diag(Gamma2) <- rep(x2, p) Z1 <- matrix(rnorm(n1*p,mean = 0,sd = 1), p, n1) Z2 <- matrix(rnorm(n2*p,mean = 0,sd = 1), p, n2) y1 <- Gamma1 %*% Z1 + mu1%*%(rep(1,n1)) y2 <- Gamma2 %*% Z2 + mu2%*%(rep(1,n2)) tsbf_zwz2023(y1, y2) #>  #>  #>  #> data:   #> statistic = 1.0408, df1 = 24.226, df2 = 1211.875, p-value = 0.4085 #>

title: Test proposed by Zhang and Zhu (2022) — tsbf_zz2022
text: Suppose two independent high-dimensional samples: $$ \boldsymbol{y}_{i1},\ldots,\boldsymbol{y}_{in_i}, \;\operatorname{\; ..d. \; }\; \operatorname{E}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\mu}_i,\; \operatorname{Cov}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_i,=1,2. $$ primary object test $$H_{0}: \boldsymbol{\mu}_1 = \boldsymbol{\mu}_2\; \operatorname{versus}\; H_{1}: \boldsymbol{\mu}_1 \neq \boldsymbol{\mu}_2.$$ Zhang Zhu (2022) proposed following test statistic: $$T_{ZZ} =  \|\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_1 - \bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_2\|^2-\operatorname{tr}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}^*_n),$$  \(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_{},=1,2\) sample mean vectors \(\hat{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}_n\) estimator \(\operatorname{Cov}(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_1-\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_2)\). showed null hypothesis, \(T_{ZZ}\) chi-squared-type mixture normal non-normal limiting distribution.

title: Test proposed by Zhang and Zhu (2022) — tsbf_zz2022
text: Zhang J, Zhu T (2022). “study Chen-Qin’s test two-sample Behrens--Fisher problems high-dimensional data.” Journal Statistical Theory Practice, 16(1), 1. doi:10.1007/s42519-021-00232-w .

title: Test proposed by Zhang and Zhu (2022) — tsbf_zz2022
code: set.seed(1234) n1 <- 20 n2 <- 30 p <- 50 mu1 <- t(t(rep(0, p))) mu2 <- mu1 rho1 <- 0.1 rho2 <- 0.2 a1 <- 1 a2 <- 2 w1 <- (-2 * sqrt(a1 * (1 - rho1)) + sqrt(4 * a1 * (1 - rho1) + 4 * p * a1 * rho1)) / (2 * p) x1 <- w1 + sqrt(a1 * (1 - rho1)) Gamma1 <- matrix(rep(w1, p * p), nrow = p) diag(Gamma1) <- rep(x1, p) w2 <- (-2 * sqrt(a2 * (1 - rho2)) + sqrt(4 * a2 * (1 - rho2) + 4 * p * a2 * rho2)) / (2 * p) x2 <- w2 + sqrt(a2 * (1 - rho2)) Gamma2 <- matrix(rep(w2, p * p), nrow = p) diag(Gamma2) <- rep(x2, p) Z1 <- matrix(rnorm(n1 * p, mean = 0, sd = 1), p, n1) Z2 <- matrix(rnorm(n2 * p, mean = 0, sd = 1), p, n2) y1 <- Gamma1 %*% Z1 + mu1 %*% (rep(1, n1)) y2 <- Gamma2 %*% Z2 + mu2 %*% (rep(1, n2)) tsbf_zz2022(y1, y2) #>  #>  #>  #> data:   #> statistic = 0.2389, df = 3.70891, beta1 = 0.62375, beta0 = -2.31342, #> p-value = 0.3515 #>

title: Test proposed by Zhang et al. (2023) — tsbf_zzz2023
text: Suppose two independent high-dimensional samples: $$ \boldsymbol{y}_{i1},\ldots,\boldsymbol{y}_{in_i}, \;\operatorname{\; ..d. \; }\; \operatorname{E}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\mu}_i,\; \operatorname{Cov}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i1})=\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_i,=1,2. $$ primary object test $$H_{0}: \boldsymbol{\mu}_1 = \boldsymbol{\mu}_2\; \operatorname{versus}\; H_{1}: \boldsymbol{\mu}_1 \neq \boldsymbol{\mu}_2.$$ Zhang et al.(2023) proposed following test statistic: $$T_{ZZZ}=\frac{n_1 n_2}{np}(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_1-\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_2)^{\top} \hat{\boldsymbol{D}}_n^{-1}(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_1-\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_2),$$ \(\bar{\boldsymbol{y}}_{},=1,2\) sample mean vectors, \(\hat{\boldsymbol{D}}_n=\operatorname{diag}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_1/n+\hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_2/n)\) \(n=n_1+n_2\). showed null hypothesis, \(T_{ZZZ}\) chi-squared-type mixture limiting distribution.

title: Test proposed by Zhang et al. (2023) — tsbf_zzz2023

title: Test proposed by Zhang et al. (2023) — tsbf_zzz2023
code: set.seed(1234) n1 <- 20 n2 <- 30 p <- 50 mu1 <- t(t(rep(0, p))) mu2 <- mu1 rho1 <- 0.1 rho2 <- 0.2 a1 <- 1 a2 <- 2 w1 <- (-2 * sqrt(a1 * (1 - rho1)) + sqrt(4 * a1 * (1 - rho1) + 4 * p * a1 * rho1)) / (2 * p) x1 <- w1 + sqrt(a1 * (1 - rho1)) Gamma1 <- matrix(rep(w1, p * p), nrow = p) diag(Gamma1) <- rep(x1, p) w2 <- (-2 * sqrt(a2 * (1 - rho2)) + sqrt(4 * a2 * (1 - rho2) + 4 * p * a2 * rho2)) / (2 * p) x2 <- w2 + sqrt(a2 * (1 - rho2)) Gamma2 <- matrix(rep(w2, p * p), nrow = p) diag(Gamma2) <- rep(x2, p) Z1 <- matrix(rnorm(n1*p,mean = 0,sd = 1), p, n1) Z2 <- matrix(rnorm(n2*p,mean = 0,sd = 1), p, n2) y1 <- Gamma1 %*% Z1 + mu1%*%(rep(1,n1)) y2 <- Gamma2 %*% Z2 + mu2%*%(rep(1,n2)) tsbf_zzz2023(y1,y2,cutoff=1.2) #>  #>  #>  #> data:   #> statistic = 0.96296, df = 24.6376, cpn = 1.4402, p-value = 0.5144 #>
